name: All Users

Community health worker

Health worker

FXREQBusinessProcesses
FXREQCategories
DakCcc
Provide a list of follow-up location options and contact details
Produce a range of prepared and ad hoc reports and analyses
Solution must be able to leverage the data dictionary (to be produced as part of workstream 2/3 work)
Allow the recording of key observations during a visit and a space to make general notes about the consultation and treatment provided
Provide a list of emergency referral locations and contact details if local emergency number (e.g. 911/999) is not used
Display a schedule of available days
Be able to view data on my own performance and service delivery

Provide a modular approach to the solution to accommodate variations required to make the solution country-specific, for example: 
- ability to use/not to use personal identifiers for registration 
- include a focus on symptoms/diagnosis that may appear in a country-susceptible manner (malaria, HIV)
- treatment modules that may be available in the country/setting (e.g. oral only vs injections)
Provide decision support as appropriate for users based on the data entered
Provide a list of referral location options, specialisms and contact details
Indicate (based on protocol) the preferred days for follow-up contact

Be able to run calculations on data to populate indicators or reports on my own performance and service delivery – calculations on data should be conducted with Fast Health Interoperability Resources (FHIR) and contextual query language
Manage clinical algorithm guidance changes through a change management process with quality assurance (using a reference system) and be able to push the information out to all solutions in use
To be able to choose the option to refer in general to the SMART guidance without having to complete a full consultation (e.g. for training/reference only)
Suggest appropriate treatments/investigations based on findings including the ability to propose alternative treatments in the case that the primary treatment is not available
Be able to find out where a treatment method may be available nearby
Record identification and tracking information (such as mobile phone number)
Be able to track treatments via reference numbers so that these can be updated as required and can be used to create "treatment modules" pertinent to a country or emergency setting
Bypass the standard flow at any point if an urgent case is identified – Refer to Business Process G. Triage and assessment
To be able to choose the option of a consultation that leads me through the full process to assess and classify the sick child and further to treat the child, referral and follow-up
Be able to show improvements or decline of a client's health based on previous/current consultations including before and after treatment
Find facilities that can provide the service or treatment method that mine cannot provide.
Display the number of existing contacts per day (to allow for balancing)
Be able to differentiate between simple and complex care provision requirements
Be able to gather the client's caregiver basic information (if required)

To be able to route the consultation via different health workers and save the information already entered to the consultation, even if the consultation is not yet complete, enabling other health workers to see the information already entered and to be able to add/edit information as it becomes available.
Provide context-sensitive, real-time decision support in response to the entry of clinical data (alerts, advice, resources)
Notify/send a reminder to the client's caregiver for the referral appointment
Be able to build the type of solution suitable for my country/setting using the correct modules according to preferences
Be able to gather unique identifier number/information pertaining to the client that does not include personal information
Identify key symptoms and signs that may require medical attention
Provide decision support as appropriate for users
Be able to share my client’s health records with the referral facility
Be able to provide feedback to the facility administrator/IT administrator for issues users notice through daily use of the tool and recommended solution improvements.
Be able to gather unique identifier number/information pertaining to the client that includes personal information
Determine whether to manage client at the facility or refer
Provide a source to access accurate health information
Notify/send a reminder to the client's caregiver for the referral appointment
The solution to support multi-media, such as video, photos and audio
Search if the client is already in system (using at least two identifiers) (including information pertaining to the client's caregiver)
View a review of any past medical history previously entered
Receive information messages in a way that ensures patient confidentiality
Provide a list or roster of all infant/child clients
The solution to store data in an FHIR-compliant server
Display sufficient data to identify the client
Create a new referral request to the health facility
Provide tools to search, sort and filter the infant/child database
Display a schedule of available days
The solution to sync data in an FHIR-compliant server
Require a user to search if a client is already in the system before starting a new medical record entry
Indicate that the patient has arrived for the initial visit, scheduled contact or specific complaint (tasks will vary based on health worker roles)
Create a new follow-up request to the health facility
Provide/print/share information/clinical guidance to the client's caregiver as relevant
Indicate (based on the protocol) the preferred days for follow-up contact
The solution to represent data in an FHIR format that can be synced with client applications that use the FHIR international patient summary (IPS) on their mobile devices
Read client identification system (e.g. quick response [QR] code, barcode, fingerprint) and pull up client information
Be able to view the age of the client on the client record or after consultation with the caregiver to add the client's age to the record
Provide decision support as appropriate for users based on the data entered
Provide a way to share sources to access to accurate health information
Record identification and tracking information (such as mobile phone number)

To be able to add data and calculations as well as forms to the reference application, for localization (language support) and adaptation (addition of core health and data content), as well as calculations for decision-support and populating indicators
Provide sufficient data to rule out that this client is already in the system
Indicate if the age of the child is not known and be able to provide information as to how an age determination has been agreed
Suggest appropriate treatments/investigations based on findings
Provide a way for the client's caregiver to receive information messages in a way that ensures patient confidentiality
Add data that provide socio-demographic information about the client
Provide a standardized form for the entry of the clients profile
Provide context-sensitive, real-time decision support in response to the entry of clinical data (alerts, advice, resources)
Be able to share my client’s health records with the follow-up facility
Edit data that provide socio-demographic information about the client
Provide a standardized form for the entry of clinical data
Provide decision support as appropriate for users based on the data entered
Be able to know the care my client received at the referral facility
Provide a list or roster of all clients in the schedule
Be able to edit the identification information (including information pertaining to the client's caregiver)
Provide real-time range checks and data integrity checks on data
Provide a source to access accurate health information
Provide a list of scheduled contacts and to allow for defaulters to be traced
Indicate mandatory fields that must be filled out for the registration to be valid
To be able to follow a consultation that focuses initially on the symptoms highlighted by the caregiver but that continues a full assessment of all possible symptoms
Receive information messages/alerts in a way that ensures patient confidentiality
Refer to Business Process A: Registration
Allow edits to fields on screen before information is committed

To be able to route the consultation via different health workers and save the information already entered to the consultation, even if the consultation is not yet complete, enabling other health workers to see the information already entered and to be able to add/edit information as it becomes available
Allow the recording of key observations during the follow-up visit
Refer to Business Process A: Registration
Allow for a temporary identification in emergency situations when full identity is unknown
Highlight abnormal values
Create a new referral request to the health facility
Be able to enter new identification information (including information pertaining to the client's caregiver)
Provide a list of tests that the health worker can order for the client based on guidance for their age/symptoms/diagnosis
Create a new follow-up request to the health facility
Indicate mandatory fields that must be filled out for the registration to be valid
Provide information so that test results that have been ordered can be recorded
Be able to start a new Business Process B: Assess and classify the sick child if new symptoms have been identified with the client
Provide/print/share information/clinical guidance with the client's caregiver as relevant
Allow edits to fields on screen before information is committed
To be able to agree/disagree with the diagnosis presented from the guidance and be able to select an alternative diagnosis stating the reasoning regarding the decision
Provide a way to share sources for access accurate health information
Allow for a temporary identification in emergency situations when full identity is unknown
Provide a standardized form for the entry of the client's profile
Provide a way for the client's caregiver to receive information messages in a way that ensures patient confidentiality
Be able to input biometric information only (e.g. age, sex, respiration, weight, birthweight, height)
Provide a standardized form for the entry of clinical data
Record a time/date-stamped new contact (encounter)
Provide real-time range checks and data integrity checks on data
Identify in the client's record if this is a follow-up appointment or an initial visit
To be able to follow a consultation that focuses initially on the symptoms highlighted by the caregiver but that continues a full assessment of all possible symptoms
Provide the ability to "check in" for a scheduled contact
Highlight abnormal values
Identify the date of the last attended contact
Provide a list of tests that the health worker can order
Provide a list of scheduled contacts to allow for defaulters to be traced
Provide fields where test results that have been ordered can be recorded
Provide a list or roster of all infant/child clients due to arrive
To be able to agree/disagree with the diagnosis presented from the guidance and be able to select an alternative diagnosis stating the reasoning regarding the decision
Provide tools to search, sort and filter the infant/child client database
Provide password-protected access for authorized users
Provide a means to ensure confidentiality and privacy of personal health information
Provide ability for allowed users to view confidential data
Anonymize data that are exported from the system when required (also ability to export non-anonymized data from the system)
Prevent remembering username and password
Automatically log out the user after specified time of inactivity
Provide encrypted communication between components
Notify the user to change their password the first time they log in
Adhere to complex password requirements
Provide a mechanism to securely change a user's password
Notify the user of a password change to their account
Reset a user's password in a secure manner
Lock a user out after a specified number of wrong password attempts
Notify a user if their account is locked due to wrong password attempts
Provide role-based access to the system
Log system log-ins and log-outs
Record all authentication violations
Log all activities performed by the user, including date and time stamp
Log access to views of individual client records
Log access to data summaries, reports, analysis and visualization features
Log exchange of data with other systems
Generate analysis of the usage of different system features and reports
Log all data and system errors
Allow user with permission to create a new user and temporary password
Provide role-based access
Allow roles to be associated with specific geographical areas and/or health facilities (with the ability to choose which facility to log into as the user may work across several facilities)
Allow cascading user management and assignment of roles
Allow user to change the user's own password
Allow users to enable and disable another user
Allow admin user to request password reset
Notify the user to regularly change the user's password
Allow each user to be assigned to one or more roles
Support definitions of unlimited roles and assigned levels of access, viewing, entry, editing and auditing
Provide a unique version number for each revision
Enable earlier versions of a record to be recoverable
Enable deployment in an environment subject to power loss
Work in an environment that is subject to loss of connectivity
Generate IDs that are unique across different installations or sites
Report version number when saving data to the database
Be designed to be flexible enough to accommodate for the necessary changes in the future
Allow for offline and online functionality
Show the number of records that are not yet synchronized
Have ability to easily back up information
Warn user if no valid back-up for more than a predefined number of days
Must have the ability to store images or other unstructured data
Scalable to accommodate new demands
Be able to accommodate at least 3000 health facilities
Be able to accommodate at least 5000 concurrent users
Be able to accommodate more than [x number of] concurrent users
Be user-friendly for people with low computer literacy
Provide informative error messages and tooltips
Alert the user when navigating away from the form without saving
Support real-time data entry validation and feedback to prevent data entry errors from being recorded
Simplify data recording through predefined dropdown or searchable lists, radio buttons and check boxes
Support multiple languages – English, French, Spanish, Chinese, Russian, Arabic
Use industry-standard user interface practices and apply them in a consistent manner throughout the system
Easy to learn and intuitive to enable user to navigate between pages
Provide guidance to the users to better support clinical guidelines and best clinical practices
Be reliable and robust (minimize the number of system crashes)
Adjust display to fit small screens (such as mobile phones)
Configure the system centrally
Configure business rules in line with guidelines and standard operating procedures (using the decision logic and contextual query language [CQL] + Fast Health Interoperability Resources [FHIR])
Configure error messages
Configure workflows and business rules to accommodate differences between facilities
Communicate with external systems through mediators
Provide access to data through application programming interfaces to interface with other SMART guideline reference App solutions, incumbent solutions (e.g. registration systems) and reporting tools
The reference application must have an FHIR back end/FHIR native and leverage the workstream 3 content (CQL + FHIR resources)
Be interoperable with external systems through mediators
Link with insurance systems to verify eligibility and submit claims
Exchange data with other approved systems
Accept data from multiple input methods including paper and geocoding (global positioning system)
Allow for data exchange and efficient synchronization across multiple facilities and points of service when the Internet is available, even when it is intermittent and slow
Enable use via a Web interface and mobile applications for use on various technology devices such as computers, laptops, tablets and mobiles
Ability to work offline and in low-bandwidth areas
Provision of design, build, technical system and architecture, and testing documentation for future support and further configuration of the solution for other health intervention initiatives
